questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with involuntary dancing movements of his right hand. He was diagnosed with rheumatic fever. What constitutes the ganglia involved in the presenting complication? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Caudate nucleus and putamen

 

Sydenham chorea is considered to be an autoimmune disease that is triggered by a streptococci infection, subsequently resulting in a hypersensitivity humoral reaction to the infection and cross-reactivity streptococci antigens and human tissue antigens through antigen mimicry.

 

The stimulated antibodies target the basal ganglia brain cells in the host and cause a diffuse inflammatory process in the corpus striatum, mainly the caudate nucleus and putamen.

 

Other Option: 

 

Option A. Caudate nucleus and globus pallidus: Incorrect. While the caudate nucleus is involved, the globus pallidus is not primarily affected in Sydenham chorea.

 

Option B. Globus pallidus and putamen: Incorrect. The globus pallidus is not primarily affected in Sydenham chorea.

 

Option C. Globus pallidus and lentiform nucleus: Incorrect. The globus pallidus is not primarily involved in Sydenham chorea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ganglia involved in Sydenham chorea, associated with rheumatic fever, are the caudate nucleus and putamen, which are part of the basal ganglia.

choices.text: A - Glucose, B - PAH, C - Bicarbonate and D - Inulin
A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH
A - PAH, B - Inulin, C - Glucose and D - Bicarbonate
A - Inulin, B - Glucose, C - Bicarbonate and D – PAH

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph given below? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D – PAH

 

The correctly matched pair of substances and their renal clearance is option B.

 

 

The concentration of the substance changes as it passes through the tubules. Removing the substance from the filtrate is k/a tubular reabsorption and adding more of the substance to the filtrate is k/a tubular secretion.

 

Amount of the substance finally excreted = Amount Filtered + Secreted - Reabsorbed

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the renal handling of different substances such as PAH, inulin, bicarbonate, and glucose is crucial for assessing kidney function and diagnosing various renal disorders. Each substance's behavior in the nephron informs clinicians about different aspects of renal physiology, such as filtration rate and tubular function.

questions.text:
Which of the following are properties of ventricular muscle fibers: (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. All or none law
  2. Length-tension relation
  3. Tetanus
  4. Long refractory period
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, and 4

 

Explanation

 

Ventricular muscle fibers exhibit several unique properties that are crucial for their function:

 

1. All or None Law: This principle states that a single muscle fiber will either contract fully or not at all in response to a stimulus. Ventricular muscle fibers act as a syncytium due to the presence of gap junctions made up of connexin proteins, which allows them to follow the all-or-none law. Thus, this property is true for ventricular muscle fibers.

 

2. Length-Tension Relation: The length-tension relationship in ventricular muscle fibers is a reflection of the Frank-Starling law, which states that the force of contraction of the heart muscle is proportional to its initial length (or end-diastolic volume, EDV). This relationship is crucial for adjusting cardiac output based on the volume of blood returning to the heart. Within physiological limits, an increase in the initial length of the muscle fiber increases the force of contraction.

 

4. Long Refractory Period: Ventricular muscle fibers have a long refractory period due to the extended plateau phase in their action potential. This long refractory period is crucial in preventing tetanus and ensuring that the heart muscle relaxes fully before the next contraction, maintaining efficient pumping action.

 

Other Option:

 

3. Tetanus: Tetanus is a sustained muscle contraction that occurs when the muscle is stimulated at a high frequency. However, due to the long refractory period in ventricular muscle fibers, tetanus is not possible. The plateau phase (phase 2) of the cardiac action potential is prolonged, which ensures that the heart muscle cannot be re-stimulated before the previous contraction is complete. This prevents sustained contractions (tetanus), which would be detrimental to cardiac function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular muscle fibers follow the all-or-none law, have a length-tension relationship (Frank-Starling law), and possess a long refractory period that prevents tetanus.

questions.text: Given below is the demonstration of tetanisation in the gastrocnemius muscle of a frog. Identify the tetanising frequency? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 20-25 Hz

 

Tetanizing frequency demonstrated by the muscle is 25Hz.

 

Tetanizing frequency: Rate of stimulation at which summation of contractions will occur

 

Tetanizing frequency can be calculated as à 1/contraction period.

 

As per the graph -

  • ﻿﻿Paper speed - 1000mm/sec.
  • ﻿﻿y-axis represents force of muscle contraction millivolts
  • x-axis represents duration of contraction in milliseconds with a scale of 10mm
  • ﻿﻿The scale on the x-axis is 10mm.
  • ﻿﻿Area under the graph is the muscle contraction.

 

Contraction period the duration from latent period to maximum force of contraction

So, in the given graph,

Contraction period is approximately 4 scales i.e., 40 mm.

As the speed of the paper is 1000mm/sec, contraction period = 40mm = (40/1000) = 40 msec = 0.04sec

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1/0.04 = 100/4 = 25Hz.

 

Educational Objective

 

Tetanisation

 

As the frequency increases, there comes a point where each new contraction occurs before the preceding one is over. As a result, the second contraction is added partially to the first, so that the total strength of contraction rises progressively with increasing frequency. When the frequency reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually become so rapid that they fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous. This is called tetanization.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for his annual check-up. He is asymptomatic but has a history of hypertension. On examination, his blood pressure is 190/100 mm Hg, and his pulse pressure is notably elevated at 90 mm Hg. He has no significant changes in his diastolic pressure compared to his previous readings, but his systolic pressure has markedly increased. Which physiological factor is likely decreased, contributing to the increased pulse pressure observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Arterial compliance

 

Explanation:

 

Arterial compliance, or the elasticity of the arterial walls, plays a critical role in dampening the fluctuations between systolic and diastolic blood pressures. Decreased arterial compliance, often due to aging or atherosclerosis, results in stiffer arteries that are less able to expand during systole. This reduced elasticity leads to a disproportionate rise in systolic pressure compared to diastolic pressure, causing an increased pulse pressure. As the arteries lose their ability to stretch and buffer the pressure changes, systolic pressure rises, contributing significantly to the elevated pulse pressure seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart rate
Heart rate affects the frequency of cardiac cycles but does not directly impact the compliance of arterial walls or significantly influence pulse pressure. Changes in heart rate would alter cardiac output but are not the primary factor influencing increased pulse pressure in this context.

 

Option C. Cardiac contractility
Increased cardiac contractility elevates stroke volume and can transiently raise systolic pressure; however, it does not specifically alter arterial compliance. Contractility does not directly affect the stiffness of arterial walls, which is the main factor influencing pulse pressure changes.

 

Option D. Blood volume
Blood volume impacts overall blood pressure but does not directly influence pulse pressure in the way arterial compliance does. Elevated blood volume would typically increase both systolic and diastolic pressures, not disproportionately affect pulse pressure alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased arterial compliance, commonly due to aging or vascular stiffness, contributes to increased pulse pressure by elevating systolic blood pressure more significantly than diastolic pressure. Arterial compliance is crucial for cushioning the pressure wave generated during systole, and its reduction leads to stiffer arteries, higher systolic pressures, and thus increased pulse pressure, a common finding in elderly or hypertensive patients.

choices.text: Segment la is due to residual urine
Segment II is due to Laplace law
Micturition fails to happen in segment II
The dotted line represents that micturition has occurred

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the given cystometrogram? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Segment II is due to Laplace Law

 

Explanation:

 

The true statement regarding the given cystometrogram is that segment lb is due to Laplace law.

 

The law of Laplace correlates volume and wall tension, is applicable to urine storage.

 

According to Law of Laplace, the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R.

 

As the bladder gets filled, the radius increases along with the tension, hence there is a slight increase in pressure until the bladder is relatively full, which explains the flatness of the graph in segment II

 

The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL. A marked sense of fullness is felt at a bladder volume of 400ml.

 

Cystometrogram is a plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder. The curve shows three segments:

 

 

  1. Initial Filling Phase (or Low-Pressure Phase): This phase represents the storage phase of bladder function.
  2. Rapid Filling Phase (or High-Pressure Phase): In this phase, the intravesical pressure increases more rapidly as the bladder volume reaches a certain threshold. The detrusor muscle, which contracts to initiate bladder emptying, starts to generate increased pressure as the bladder approaches its capacity. This phase represents the transition from storage to voiding phase.
  3. Voiding Phase (or Micturition Phase): In the voiding phase, the intravesical pressure rises to its highest level as the detrusor muscle contracts forcefully to empty the bladder. The pressure exceeds the urethral resistance, resulting in urine expulsion. This phase is associated with the sensation of needing to urinate and the act of micturition (urination).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Segment Ia is due to residual urine: Incorrect. Segment I, particularly the initial part of the curve, typically represents the early filling phase of the bladder, not necessarily residual urine.

 

Option C. Micturition fails to happen in segment II: Incorrect. Segment II represents the continuation of the filling phase; micturition (urination) does not occur here because it typically begins when the bladder reaches its threshold capacity and the detrusor muscle contracts, which would be represented later in the graph.

 

Option D. The dotted line represents that micturition has occurred: Incorrect. The dotted line likely indicates phase transitions within the bladder's filling and voiding cycle, not necessarily the occurrence of micturition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Segment II of a cystometrogram, characterized by Laplace's Law, illustrates how the bladder can accommodate increasing volumes of urine with minimal increase in pressure, showcasing the bladder's compliance during the urine storage phase. This is crucial for diagnosing and managing conditions related to bladder storage and voiding dysfunction.

questions.text: In a patient with suspected endocrine dysfunction, which hormone primarily acts through the signaling pathway shown in the diagram below, potentially contributing to the patient's condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leptin

 

The provided image depicts the JAK-STAT signaling pathway, known for its association with tyrosine kinase receptors. Within this pathway, leptin operates as one of the hormones involved. Leptin binds to its receptor, activating the JAK-STAT signaling cascade. This pathway is crucial for regulating energy balance and body weight, and its dysfunction can lead to endocrine and metabolic disorders. Leptin's role in this pathway highlights its importance in physiological processes and potential involvement in the patient's endocrine dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcitonin: Calcitonin primarily uses a different signaling mechanism involving G-protein-coupled receptors, not the JAK-STAT pathway.

 

Option C. Vasopressin: Vasopressin operates through G-protein-coupled receptors, particularly influencing water reabsorption in the kidneys, and does not utilize the JAK-STAT signaling pathway.

 

Option D. Aldosterone: Aldosterone acts mainly through mineralocorticoid receptors, influencing sodium and potassium balance in the kidneys, and is not involved in the JAK-STAT signaling pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Strength of muscle contraction
Intensity of stimulus
Amplitude of action potential
Duration of stimulus

questions.text: Weber-Fechner law relates magnitude of sensation to? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intensity of stimulus

 

The Weber-Fechner law is a psychophysical law that describes the relationship between the magnitude of a physical stimulus and the perceived intensity of the resulting sensation.

 

According to this law, the perceived magnitude of a sensory stimulus is proportional to the logarithm of the stimulus intensity. In other words, as the intensity of the stimulus increases, the change needed to produce a noticeable difference in sensation also increases, and this relationship is logarithmic rather than linear.

 

The law was first formulated by the German scientists Ernst Heinrich Weber and Gustav Theodor Fechner in the mid-19th century and has since been applied to a wide range of sensory modalities, including vision, hearing, and touch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strength of muscle contraction: This is unrelated to the Weber-Fechner law, which does not concern muscle contraction.

 

Option C. Amplitude of action potential: While action potentials are critical for neural transmission, the Weber-Fechner law specifically relates to the perception of stimulus intensity, not the electrical properties of neurons.

 

Option D. Duration of stimulus: The duration of a stimulus affects perception in different ways but is not the focus of the Weber-Fechner law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Weber-Fechner law illustrates the logarithmic relationship between the actual intensity of a stimulus and the perceived intensity, emphasizing that the human sensory system scales the perception of stimulus magnitude logarithmically rather than linearly.

 

Additional information Other Laws in Physiology:

 

  • Doctrine of specific nerve energies states that the nature of perception is defined by the pathway over which the sensory information is carried. Hence, the origin of the sensation is not important.
  • Law of projection - Regardless of stimulation point for a particular sensory pathway (along its course to cortex), conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of receptor.

questions.text: The motor supply of the muscle spindle is which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gamma neuron

 

Gamma motor neurons specifically innervate the intrafusal fibers within the muscle spindles, adjusting their tension and sensitivity to stretch, which is crucial for proper proprioceptive feedback.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha (α) neuron: Alpha motor neurons innervate extrafusal muscle fibers, which are the main contractile units of the muscle, and are not involved in the direct control of muscle spindle sensitivity.

 

Option C. Beta (β) neuron: A Beta neurons are sensory in nature, so they neither supply extrafusal nor intrafusal muscle fibers.

 

Option D. Delta (δ) neuron: Delta neurons are sensory neurons that transmit pain, temperature, and coarse touch sensations. They do not provide motor supply to muscle spindles or any other muscle fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gamma motor neurons (A gamma) specifically innervate the intrafusal fibers of muscle spindles, adjusting their tension and sensitivity to stretch, which is crucial for proper proprioceptive feedback.

questions.text: Least frequency of slow waves is seen in? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stomach

 

Among the given options, the least frequency of slow waves is seen in the stomach (4/min).

 

Most gastrointestinal contractions occur rhythmically, and this rhythm is determined mainly by the frequency of so-called “slow waves” of smooth muscle membrane potential or basal electrical rhythm.

 

Interactions among the smooth muscle cells and specialized cells, called the interstitial cells of Cajal, that are believed to act as electrical pacemakers for smooth muscle cells.

 

They are slow, undulating changes in the resting membrane potential. Their intensity usually varies between 5 and 15 millivolts, and their frequency ranges in different parts of the human gastrointestinal tract from 3 to 12 per minute:

 

  • Body of the stomach – 3/min
  • Duodenum – 12/min
  • Terminal ileum – 8-9/min
  • Distal ileum: 8/min
  • Cecum: 2/min
  • Sigmoid colon: 6/min

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenum: Incorrect. The duodenum has a higher frequency of slow waves, approximately 12 waves per minute.

 

Option B. Ileum: Incorrect. The terminal ileum has a frequency of about 8-9 waves per minute.

 

Option C. Jejunum: Incorrect. The jejunum has a frequency of approximately 10-12 waves per minute.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stomach has the least frequency of slow waves among the given options, with approximately 3 waves per minute. Slow waves determine the rhythmic contractions of the gastrointestinal tract and vary in frequency throughout different regions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dietary fiber? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Milk

 

Explanation

 

Major components of dietary fiber are cellulose, hemicelluloses, D-glucans, pectin, lignin and gums. Cellulose, hemicelluloses and pectin are partially degradable, while other components are indigestible. Dietary fiber also contains minerals, antioxidants and other chemicals that are useful for health.

 

Sources of dietary fiber are fruits, vegetables, cereals, bread and wheat grain (particularly its outer layer).

 

Diet with high dietary fiber has health benefits since dietary fiber:

 

  1. Delays emptying of stomach
  2. Increases formation of bulk and soft feces and eases defecation
  3. Contains substances such as antioxidants and other useful substances

 

Diet with high fiber content tends to be low in energy and it may be useful in reducing the body weight.

 

Some components of dietary fiber also reduce blood cholesterol level and thereby decrease the risk for coronary heart disease and gallstones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cellulose: A primary form of dietary fiber found in the cell walls of plants.

 

Option B. Inulin: A type of soluble fiber found in many plants, used by some as a prebiotic to promote gut health.

 

Option C. Pectin: Another soluble fiber, pectin is commonly found in fruits and used to help gel liquids, also aiding in digestion and cholesterol reduction.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Inside the membrane
At the C-terminal
At the N-terminal
Both inside the membrane and at C- terminal

questions.text: The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein with N-terminal facing cytoplasm is located in?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inside the membrane

 

The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein is located inside the membrane.

 

These sequences usually have methionine as the terminal amino acid.

 

Transmembrane proteins are integral proteins that span across the plasma/ endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membrane. They are classified into types 1 to 4. –

 

Type 1 membrane proteins have a cleavable N-terminal signal sequence outside the cell, a transmembrane sequence that is usually situated close to the C-terminus and the C-terminus facing inside the cell, e.g., low-density lipoprotein receptor.

 

Type 2 membrane proteins have the N-terminal towards the cytosol and the C-terminal towards the exterior, e.g., transferrin receptor.

 

Type 3 membrane proteins are identical to type 1 but have a shorter N terminal, e.g., cytochrome P450 enzyme complexes.

 

Type 4 membrane proteins consist of 7 alpha helices traversing the membrane, e.g., glucose transporters and G-protein-coupled receptors.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. At the C-terminal: This is incorrect because the signaling sequence in type 2 membrane proteins is not located at the C-terminal.

 

Option C. At the N-terminal: This is incorrect as well. In type 2 membrane proteins, the N-terminal is facing the cytoplasm, but the signaling sequence itself is located inside the membrane.

 

Option D. Both inside the membrane and at C-terminal: This is incorrect because the signaling sequence is located specifically inside the membrane, not at the C-terminal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signaling sequence in type 2 membrane proteins is located inside the membrane, crucial for the proper orientation and insertion of the protein.

choices.text: No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic membrane
Connexons are involved in electrical synapse
Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse

questions.text: How is an electrical synapse different from a chemical synapse? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Connexons are involved in electrical synapse

 

 

Electrical synapses are characterized by direct open fluid channels that conduct electricity from one cell to the next. Most of these consist of small protein tubular structures called gap junctions (connexons) that allow free movement of ions from the interior of one cell to the interior of the next. By way of gap junctions and other similar junctions that action potentials are transmitted from one smooth muscle fiber to the next in visceral smooth muscle and from one cardiac muscle cell to the next in cardiac muscle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic membrane: Incorrect. This statement describes chemical synapses, not electrical synapses.

 

Option B. Direction of impulse is unidirectional: Incorrect. Electrical synapses can conduct impulses bidirectionally, whereas chemical synapses typically conduct impulses unidirectionally.

 

Option D. Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse: Incorrect. Electrical synapses have a shorter latent period compared to chemical synapses due to the direct transfer of ions through connexons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electrical synapses involve connexons, which are gap junctions that allow direct ion flow between adjacent cells, facilitating rapid and synchronized electrical communication.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of difficulty recognizing people, including her family and friends, by their faces alone. She reports that she often fails to recognize familiar individuals unless they speak or she notices distinctive features like their clothing or hairstyle. Despite this, she has no trouble recognizing objects or places, and her memory for events remains intact. A neurological exam is normal, and her vision is unimpaired. Brain MRI shows subtle abnormalities in the right fusiform gyrus. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Prosopagnosia

 

Explanation:

 

Prosopagnosia, also known as face blindness, is a neurological condition characterized by the inability to recognize familiar faces. This disorder is often linked to damage or dysfunction in the right fusiform gyrus, a region in the brain involved in facial perception and recognition. Patients with prosopagnosia may retain the ability to recognize people by other cues, such as voice or distinctive clothing, but struggle specifically with facial recognition. Prosopagnosia can be congenital or acquired due to brain injury, stroke, or neurodegenerative conditions, and it is not associated with general memory impairment, vision problems, or intellectual disabilities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Visual agnosia
Visual agnosia is a disorder where the patient cannot recognize objects despite having intact vision. It differs from prosopagnosia as it involves difficulties in object recognition rather than specific problems with face recognition.

 

Option C. Anterograde amnesia
Anterograde amnesia refers to the inability to form new memories following an event, such as a brain injury. It affects the encoding and storage of new information rather than the recognition of faces, making it distinct from prosopagnosia.

 

Option D. Balint’s syndrome
Balint’s syndrome is a rare neurological disorder characterized by difficulties in spatial processing, including optic ataxia and gaze apraxia, but it does not specifically affect facial recognition. The primary issues involve visual attention and coordination rather than face perception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prosopagnosia, or face blindness, is a condition characterized by the inability to recognize familiar faces, often due to damage or dysfunction in the right fusiform gyrus of the brain. It can be congenital or acquired and is not associated with general memory deficits, impaired vision, or other cognitive dysfunctions. Recognizing this condition is crucial in distinguishing it from other neurological disorders that affect memory or object recognition.

questions.text:
Countercurrent mechanism is present in which of the following parts of the body?(INICET Nov 2022)

 

1. Eye

2. Testes

3. Kidney

4. Gut

5. Lungs
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1,2,3,4,5 are correct

 

The countercurrent mechanism is present in various parts of the body where the inflow and outflow run parallel and in opposite directions, facilitating efficient exchange processes:

 

  1. Eye: The theory of counter-current mechanisms predicts that there is diffusion of oxygen from retinal arterioles into adjacent retinal venules. A possible counter-current exchange was investigated by measuring hemoglobin oxygen saturation (SatO2) in first-order retinal arterioles and venules at different distances from the optic disc.
  2. Testes: The temperature is regulated to be low for spermatogenesis by heat exchange between spermatic arteries and veins in a countercurrent manner.
  3. Kidney: The urine is concentrated using countercurrent exchangers, particularly in the loop of Henle and the vasa recta.
  4. Gut: Certain parts of the gut use countercurrent mechanisms to optimize nutrient absorption.
  5. Lungs: Countercurrent mechanisms in the lungs help in efficient gas exchange.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The countercurrent mechanism is a biological system found in various organs such as the eye, testes, kidney, gut, and lungs, allowing for efficient exchange and regulation processes.

choices.text: Intracellular fluid
Extracellular fluid

questions.text: A body fluid sample is being studied and has Na: 10 mEq/L, K: 140 mEq/L, CI: 4 mE/L. Identify the compartment from which the sample has been obtained? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intracellular fluid

 

Explanation

 

The electrolyte composition in the sample obtained has high concentration of potassium, suggests that it is intracellular fluid (IC) compartment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial and Option C. Extracellular Fluid generally have higher sodium and chloride concentrations and much lower potassium concentrations.

 

Option D. Plasma, part of the extracellular fluid, would similarly show higher sodium and chloride but lower potassium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The composition of potassium, sodium, and chloride in the sample aligns with that typically found in intracellular fluid, reflecting its origin from within cells, where potassium is the major cation, unlike extracellular compartments dominated by sodium and chloride.

questions.text: Which of the following is not found in the area indicated by the arrow in the provided image of cardiac muscle?(AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Zona occludens

 

Explanation:

 

This shows the intercalated discs of cardiac muscle cells. These specialized structures link heart cells together, facilitating synchronized contraction. Intercalated discs contain fascia adherens (which anchor actin filaments and provide mechanical stability), macula adherens (desmosomes, which prevent cells from separating during contraction), and gap junctions (which allow for ionic and electrical continuity among cardiac cells). However, they do not include zona occludens, or tight junctions, which typically seal adjacent cells in epithelial tissues to prevent passage of molecules between them. In cardiac muscle, tight junctions are not a component of the intercalated discs, as these discs are primarily focused on mechanical stability and electrical coupling rather than creating a barrier.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option B (Fascia adherens) and Option C (Macula adherens) are incorrect choices for exclusion because both are integral components of the intercalated discs, providing the required mechanical strength and stability.
  • Option D (Gap junction) is also incorrect to exclude as it is crucial for the electrical connectivity needed for the heart muscle's synchronized contractions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intercalated discs of cardiac muscle do not contain zona occludens. They are composed instead of fascia adherens, macula adherens (desmosomes), and gap junctions.

questions.text: The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the segment with the bolus of food during peristalsis is because of? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) VIP

 

The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the segment with the bolus of food during peristalsis is due to the release of VIP (Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide) from the enteric nervous system.

 

VIP is a neuropeptide that is released by neurons in the myenteric plexus of the enteric nervous system. It causes relaxation of the smooth muscle in the intestinal wall, including the distal segment, through its action on VIP receptors located on the smooth muscle cells. This relaxation allows the bolus of food to move smoothly along the digestive tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Substance P: Incorrect. Substance P is a neuropeptide involved in the regulation of gastrointestinal motility, primarily stimulating smooth muscle contraction rather than relaxation.

 

Option C. Dopamine from adrenergic fibres: Incorrect. Dopamine from adrenergic fibers is involved in the regulation of gastrointestinal motility, but it is not specifically responsible for the relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the bolus of food during peristalsis.

 

Option D. Acetylcholine from myenteric fibres: Incorrect. Acetylcholine from myenteric fibers is a neurotransmitter involved in the regulation of gastrointestinal motility, typically promoting contraction rather than relaxation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the bolus of food during peristalsis is mediated by the release of Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide (VIP) from the enteric nervous system, which causes smooth muscle relaxation and facilitates the smooth movement of the bolus through the digestive tract.

choices.text: Sense changes in muscle direction
Sense changes in muscle tension
Sense changes in position of the muscle
Sense changes in length of the muscle

questions.text: The function of the Golgi tendon organ is to? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sense changes in muscle tension

 

The Golgi tendon organ functions as a crucial sensory receptor that provides important feedback to the central nervous system, contributing to muscle control, injury prevention, and maintaining appropriate muscle tension during various activities.

 

The Golgi tendon organ is an encapsulated sensory receptor through which muscle tendon fibers pass. About 10 to 15 muscle fibers are usually connected to each Golgi tendon organ, and the organ is stimulated when this small bundle of muscle fibers is “tensed” by contracting or stretching the muscle.

 

The major difference in excitation of the Golgi tendon organ versus the muscle spindle is that the spindle detects muscle length and changes in muscle length, whereas the tendon organ detects muscle tension as reflected by the tension in itself.

 

Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex)

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Sense changes in muscle direction: Incorrect. Muscle direction changes are not detected by the Golgi tendon organ but by proprioceptors in the muscle and joints.

 

Option C. Sense changes in position of the muscle: Incorrect. This function is primarily performed by muscle spindles and joint receptors, not by the Golgi tendon organ.

 

Option D. Sense changes in length of the muscle: Incorrect. Muscle spindles are responsible for detecting changes in muscle length and the rate of change in length, not the Golgi tendon organ.

 

Educational Objective

 

The Golgi tendon organ is responsible for sensing changes in muscle tension, providing crucial feedback to the central nervous system to prevent muscle damage and maintain appropriate muscle tension during various activities.

questions.text: After reaching an equilibrium state during exercising, it was found that the body was consuming oxygen at the rate of 1500 ml/min. Calculate the MET score if the baseline oxygen consumption at rest is 250 ml/min? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6

 

MET (Metabolic Equivalent) is a unit used to estimate the energy expenditure of physical activities as a multiple of the resting metabolic rate (RMR). One MET is equal to the energy expended at rest, which is approximately 3.5 mL of oxygen per kilogram of body weight per minute (ml/kg/min).

 

To calculate the MET score for a given level of oxygen consumption, we need to first convert the oxygen consumption rate from ml/min to ml/kg/min, and then divide it by the resting oxygen consumption rate to get the MET value.

 

Assuming an average body weight of 70 kg, the oxygen consumption rate of 1500 ml/min corresponds to 21.4 ml/kg/min (1500 ml/min ÷ 70 kg).

 

Dividing this value by the resting oxygen consumption rate of 250 ml/min, we get:

 

MET score = 21.4 ml/kg/min ÷ 3.5 ml/kg/min ≈ 6

 

Therefore, the correct answer is B. 6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The MET score represents the energy expenditure of an activity as a multiple of the resting metabolic rate.

questions.text: Where do afferent fibers from baroreceptors primarily project for blood pressure control? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nucleus Tractus Solitarius

 

Afferent fiber for blood pressure control goes to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS).

 

The afferent fibers from baroreceptors for blood pressure control primarily project to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS). The NTS is located in the medulla oblongata, which is part of the brainstem. It serves as the primary site for integrating and processing information related to blood pressure regulation.

 

The baroreceptors are specialized sensory receptors located in the walls of certain blood vessels, particularly in the carotid sinus and aortic arch. These receptors detect changes in blood pressure and relay this information via afferent (sensory) nerve fibers. The afferent fibers from the baroreceptors transmit signals to the NTS, where they are integrated and contribute to the regulation of blood pressure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nucleus ambiguous: Incorrect. This nucleus is involved in controlling the muscles of the pharynx, larynx, and soft palate.

 

Option B. Rostral-ventrolateral medulla: Incorrect. This area is involved in the regulation of sympathetic outflow but does not receive direct input from baroreceptor afferents.

 

Option D. Caudal ventrolateral medulla: Incorrect. This area is involved in regulating blood pressure but is not the primary projection site for baroreceptor afferents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Afferent fibers from baroreceptors project to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS) in the medulla oblongata, where they integrate and process information related to blood pressure regulation.

choices.text: Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

questions.text: Which of the following is not required for calculation of creatinine clearance? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

 

The volume of plasma passing through the kidney in 24 hours is not used in the calculation of creatinine clearance.

 

Other Options:

 

The calculation of creatinine clearance involves the following parameters:

 

Option A. Urine creatinine concentration: This is the amount of creatinine present in the urine, typically measured in milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL).

 

Option B. Serum creatinine concentration: This is the amount of creatinine present in the blood, also measured in milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL).

 

Option C. 24-hour urine output: This is the total volume of urine produced in 24 hours, measured in milliliters (mL).

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus
When 02 and CO2 ratio is equal
The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg

questions.text: V/Q = infinity holds true in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Equal to dead space

 

Explanation

 

VA/Q= infinity suggests that Q is 0 which implies that there is no exchange of 02 & CO2, and no gaseous exchange occurs in dead space.

 

In quantitative terms, the ventilation-perfusion ratio is expressed as Va/Q. When Va (alveolar ventilation) is normal for a given alveolus and Q (blood flow) is also normal for the same alveolus, the ventilation-perfusion ratio (Va/Q) is also said to be normal.

 

This ratio explains the respiratory exchange when there is an imbalance between alveolar ventilation and alveolar blood flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus: Incorrect, as this condition would lead to an area with no ventilation (blocked by the foreign body) potentially resulting in a low V/Q ratio in the affected area rather than an infinite V/Q ratio.

 

Option C. When O2 and CO2 ratio is equal: Incorrect, as this does not directly relate to the ventilation-perfusion ratio concept. This option is more a reflection of gas exchange effectiveness rather than a description of V/Q mismatches.

 

Option D. The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg: Incorrect, these values are typical for normal alveolar air and do not indicate a V/Q mismatch situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VA /Q ratio is infinite in the following scenarios -

 

  1. Ventilation is normal but there is no perfusion.
  2. No gaseous exchange through the respiratory membranes of corresponding alveoli.
  3. The alveolar air equilibrates the humidified inspired air.
  4. Partial pressures of the 02 and CO, are 149 mmHg & 0 mm Hg respectively.

choices.text: Forced expiration against a closed glottis
Forced expiration against an open glottis
Forced inspiration against a closed glottis

questions.text: Which of the following occur during the beginning cough reflex? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Forced expiration against a closed glottis

 

The cough reflex begins with a forced expiration against a closed glottis. The pressure builds up in the lungs and, when the glottis opens, it allows for a rapid expulsion of air to clear the airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Forced expiration against an open glottis: This does not occur during a cough reflex. While the glottis does eventually open to allow air to be expelled, the characteristic high-pressure expulsion of air is the result of the closed glottis after which it opens.

 

Option C. Forced inspiration against a closed glottis: Inspiration occurs with an open glottis. A closed glottis would prevent air from entering the lungs, so this does not occur during the cough reflex.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because option (a) accurately describes an event that occurs during the cough reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The beginning of the cough reflex involves a forced expiration against a closed glottis, building up pressure in the lungs which is then rapidly released when the glottis opens.Top of Form

questions.text: What is the value of the endocochlear potential? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: D. +85 mV

 

Explanation:

 

The endocochlear potential is a crucial electrical potential found within the scala media of the cochlea, which is significantly higher compared to surrounding areas. This potential, approximately +85 mV, is primarily generated by the active transport of potassium ions into the scala media by the stria vascularis. The high potassium concentration within the endolymph contributes to this unique positive potential. This electrical gradient is essential for the proper function of hair cells in the inner ear, playing a critical role in the transduction of sound vibrations into electrical signals that can be interpreted by the brain.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A (+45 mV) and Option B (–45 mV) are incorrect as they do not match the recognized value for endocochlear potential which is distinctly positive and higher than +45 mV.
  • Option C (–60mV) also does not fit as the potential is not only incorrect in value but also incorrectly marked as negative, whereas the endocochlear potential is a positive value.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The endocochlear potential is characterized by a significant positive value of approximately +85 mV, crucial for the activation of transduction mechanisms within cochlear hair cells. This positive potential facilitates the conversion of mechanical sound waves into electrochemical signals.

questions.text: A 37-year-old presented with fever. On examination, he had enlarged and ulcerated tonsils. His peripheral blood smear showed lymphocytosis. Monospot test was negative. Tonsillectomy was done and it showed large cells mixed with lymphocytes. The cells were positive for CD20, EB LMP1, MUM1, CD 79a. Background cells were positive for CD3. The cells are negative for CD15. Your most probable diagnosis is? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) EBV positive – DLBCL, NOS

 

The given clinical scenario suggests a likely diagnosis of EB positive DLBCL, NOS (Epstein Barr virus-positive Diffuse Large B Cell Lymphoma, not otherwise specified.

 

The given slide shows sheets of large lymphoid cells with irregular vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli typical of DLBCL.

 

Approach to the question:

 

  • Negative monospot test rules out the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis
  • Absence of Reed-Sternberg cell or its variants rules out Hodgkins lymphoma.
  • EBV-positive mucocutaneous ulcer is seen in immunocompromised individuals presenting as self-limiting ulcer which subsides on treatment. Biopsy will show atypical large B cells with RS cell-like morphology. Hence, this is cannot be the diagnosis.

 

EBV positive DLBCL (Diffuse Large B Cell Lymphoma)

 

  • Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of NHL.
  • Age > 50yrs
  • No past history of lymphoma
  • Presents as a rapidly enlarging mass at nodal or extra-nodal site.
  • Immunodeficiency-associated large B-cell lymphoma occurs in the setting of severe T-cell
  • immunodeficiency (e.g., advanced HIV infection and allogeneic bone marrow transplantation). The neoplastic B cells are usually infected with EBV, which plays a critical pathogenic role. Restoration of T-cell immunity may lead to regression of these proliferations
  • Immunohistochemistry is positive for CD 20, CD 79a, IRF4/MUM1. EBV LMP-1 (Latent membrane protein-1) is positive in about 2/3rd of cases, while EBNA-2 (Epstein-Barr nuclear antigen) is positive in the remaining 1/3rd of cases. It is negative for CD10 and BCL6.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hodgkin lymphoma: This diagnosis is less likely because Hodgkin lymphoma typically presents with Reed-Sternberg cells, which are positive for CD15 and CD30, not the immunophenotype seen in this case.

 

Option C. Infectious mononucleosis: This condition is ruled out by the negative Monospot test and the presence of large atypical cells positive for B cell markers, which are more indicative of lymphoma.

 

Option D. EBV positive mucocutaneous ulcer: This condition usually occurs in immunocompromised individuals and presents as a self-limiting ulcer. The biopsy may show atypical large B cells with RS cell-like morphology, but the clinical scenario and histopathological findings are more consistent with EBV positive DLBCL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most probable diagnosis for a patient with enlarged, ulcerated tonsils, lymphocytosis, a negative Monospot test, and immunohistochemical findings of CD20, EB LMP1, MUM1, and CD79a positivity is EBV positive Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma, NOS.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 1121-1123

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presents with a progressive decline in daily activity. She gives a history of staring into space with frequent visual hallucinations. Pathology reveals Lewy bodies in neurons. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Parkinson’s Disease

 

The presence of Lewy bodies, which are aggregates of alpha-synuclein protein, in neurons suggests either Parkinson's disease or Lewy body dementia. Given the patient's symptoms of progressive decline in daily activity, visual hallucinations, and pathology findings, Parkinson's disease is the most likely diagnosis.

 

  • Lewy Bodies: These are characteristic of Parkinson’s disease and Lewy body dementia. They are intraneuronal inclusions primarily composed of alpha-synuclein.
  • Visual Hallucinations: These are more common in Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia compared to other neurodegenerative disorders.
  • Parkinson’s Disease: The diagnosis is supported by the clinical history of visual hallucinations and progressive decline, alongside the pathological finding of Lewy bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prion’s Disease: Typically presents with rapidly progressing dementia and myoclonus. EEG shows characteristic periodic sharp wave complexes, and CSF may show elevated 14.3.3 protein. This does not match the patient's clinical picture.

 

Option C. Huntington’s Disease: An inherited condition characterized by the classic triad of dementia, chorea, and psychiatric manifestations. This condition usually presents earlier in life and has a strong family history component.

 

Option D. Alzheimer’s Disease: Primarily presents with memory loss and later with visual-spatial problems and the "four A’s" (amnesia, agnosia, apraxia, aphasia). Pathologically, it is characterized by beta-amyloid plaques and tau protein tangles, not Lewy bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Lewy bodies in neurons and clinical features such as visual hallucinations and progressive decline in activity are indicative of Parkinson’s disease.

questions.text: 22-year-old patient with high myopia and thick glasses presents with floaters in his eyes. What is the cause of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retinal detachment

 

Retinal detachment occurs when the sensory retina separates from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium. This separation can be due to a retinal break, known as rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, which is the most common type. In patients with high myopia, there is an increased risk of peripheral retinal degeneration, leading to retinal holes that can progress to retinal detachment. The presence of floaters and flashes is a key symptom indicating retinal detachment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: This condition typically presents with sudden severe headache and neurological symptoms rather than visual symptoms like floaters.

 

Option C. Vitreous hemorrhage: While this can cause floaters, it is more commonly associated with trauma, diabetic retinopathy, or vascular abnormalities rather than high myopia.

 

Option D. Branched retinal artery occlusion: This condition usually presents with sudden, painless loss of vision in part of the visual field rather than floaters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with high myopia are at increased risk for peripheral retinal degeneration and subsequent retinal detachment, presenting with symptoms like floaters and flashes.

questions.text: When you add calcium and thromboplastin to platelet poor plasma which pathway is assessed? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extrinsic

 

Thromboplastin (Factor III) binds with Factor VII. When calcium is added, it activates extrinsic pathway.

 

 

Activated Prothrombin Time (aPTT) measures the integrity of the intrinsic system (Factors XII, XI, VIII, IX) and common clotting pathways. Calcium and activating substances (kaolin) are added to the plasma-

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Intrinsic: The intrinsic pathway is assessed using the Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT) test, where calcium and an activating substance like kaolin (not thromboplastin) are added to the plasma to measure the activity of Factors XII, XI, IX, and VIII.

 

Option C. Fibrinolysis: Fibrinolysis is the process of breaking down fibrin clots, which is not directly assessed by adding thromboplastin and calcium. It is evaluated by other means, such as measuring fibrin degradation products (FDPs) or D-dimer levels.

 

Option D. Common: While the extrinsic pathway feeds into the common pathway (Factors X, V, II, and I), the specific test described (PT) is primarily assessing the extrinsic pathway, though it also gives some information about the common pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adding calcium and thromboplastin to platelet-poor plasma assesses the extrinsic pathway of coagulation, which is the basis for the Prothrombin Time (PT) test.

choices.text: Zona Occludens (Tight Junctions)
Villi of the small intestine

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe watery diarrhea that resembles rice water stools, a hallmark of a specific gastrointestinal infection. He reports recent travel to a region known for poor sanitation and contaminated water supplies. On examination, he appears dehydrated with signs of hypovolemia. Stool studies reveal a high volume of watery discharge with no significant blood or mucus. Which structure's damage is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Zona Occludens (Tight Junctions)

 

Explanation:

 

Zona Occludens, or tight junctions, are critical structures located at the apical end of epithelial cells in the gastrointestinal tract. These junctions create a barrier that regulates the passage of ions, water, and other substances between cells, maintaining the integrity of the intestinal lining. When these tight junctions are damaged, such as by bacterial toxins or viral infections, they lose their selective permeability, leading to a breakdown of the intestinal barrier. This damage allows an unregulated flow of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, resulting in the characteristic severe, watery diarrhea seen in conditions like cholera.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Villi of the small intestine
Villi are finger-like projections that increase the absorptive surface area of the small intestine but are not directly responsible for maintaining intestinal barrier integrity. Damage to villi typically leads to malabsorption and steatorrhea rather than severe watery diarrhea.

 

Option C. Goblet cells
Goblet cells are responsible for secreting mucus, which protects the intestinal lining but does not play a role in tight junction integrity. Damage to goblet cells usually results in decreased mucus production, leading to irritation and less protection of the intestinal surface, but not directly causing watery diarrhea.

 

Option D. Peyer's patches
Peyer's patches are lymphoid tissues in the small intestine that play a role in immune surveillance but are not involved in regulating the intestinal barrier's permeability. Damage to these patches may impact immune function but does not directly cause diarrhea resembling rice water stools.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The integrity of the intestinal barrier is maintained by tight junctions, also known as Zona Occludens, which regulate the passage of water and electrolytes. Damage to these junctions due to toxins or infections can disrupt this barrier, leading to increased permeability and severe watery diarrhea, as seen in conditions like cholera. Understanding the role of tight junctions is crucial in managing gastrointestinal diseases characterized by barrier dysfunction.

questions.text: Highest thermic effect?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proteins

 

Proteins have the highest thermic effect among the three macronutrients. When you consume protein-rich foods, your body needs to expend more energy to break down and process the proteins. This is because proteins are composed of amino acids, and the body requires energy to convert them into usable forms. The thermic effect of proteins ranges from 20% to 30% of the total caloric intake from protein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbohydrates: Carbohydrates have a moderate thermic effect. The thermic effect of carbohydrates ranges from 5% to 10% of the total caloric intake from carbohydrates.

 

Option C. Fats: Fats have the lowest thermic effect among the macronutrients. The thermic effect of fats ranges from 0% to 5% of the total caloric intake from fats.

 

Option D. Fatty acids: Fatty acids are the building blocks of fats, and their thermic effect is similar to that of fats.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thermic effect of food (TEF) refers to the increase in energy expenditure that occurs during the digestion, absorption, and metabolism of nutrients in the body. This effect varies depending on the macronutrient composition of the food consumed.

questions.text: According to IADPSG, what is the cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) > 92 mg/dL

 

Explanation:

 

The International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG) has established criteria for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). According to their guidelines:

 

  • The fasting blood glucose cut-off value for diagnosing GDM during a 75g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is >92 mg/dL.

 

This value is used as part of a comprehensive assessment, including 1-hour and 2-hour postprandial glucose levels. The IADPSG criteria for GDM diagnosis include:

 

  • Fasting: ≥92 mg/dL
  • 1-hour: ≥180 mg/dL
  • 2-hour: ≥153 mg/dL

 

If any one of these values is abnormal, the diagnosis of GDM can be made.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. >95 mg/dL: This is not the IADPSG recommended cut-off for fasting blood glucose. It is higher than the specified cut-off value for diagnosing GDM.

 

Option C. >106 mg/dL: This value is significantly higher than the recommended cut-off. It exceeds the threshold for diagnosing GDM according to IADPSG guidelines.

 

Option D. >90 mg/dL: While this value is close, it is slightly below the IADPSG recommended cut-off of >92 mg/dL for diagnosing GDM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus according to IADPSG is >92 mg/dL.

 

Ref: Page no 326, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a good prognostic factor in schizophrenia? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insidious onset of symptoms

 

Insidious onset of symptoms, where the symptoms develop slowly and subtly over time, tends to indicate a poorer prognosis when compared to an abrupt or sudden onset of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Schizophrenia's prognosis varies based on several factors:

 

Option A. Positive symptoms: Positive symptoms such as hallucinations and delusions are usually more responsive to antipsychotic medications, marking them as a better prognostic factor.

 

Option B. Late age of onset: Late age of onset indeed is a better prognostic factor. Early-onset schizophrenia tends to be more severe and has a poorer prognosis than schizophrenia that begins in adulthood.

 

Option D. Associated with depression: If a patient with schizophrenia also has depressive symptoms, the prognosis might be somewhat better since affective symptoms might respond to treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 62.

questions.text: Amongst the poisons given below, which poison can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arsenic

 

Arsenic gets fixed to the bones and gets released from it very slowly over a period of time and thus can be detected in the bones for several years after death.

 

Toxicokinetic of Arsenic:

 

  1. Because of short half-life of arsenic in the blood, arsenic is rapidly cleared from the blood. Hence it is less reliable to detect arsenic poisoning.
  2. After clearing from blood, arsenic gets deposited in almost all the tissues where it is found for prolonged period. However, arsenic does not cross blood brain barrier.
  3. Highest concentration is found in liver (followed by kidney)
  4. Urine becomes positive within 6 hours of poisoning and may continue to be positive for about 2-3 weeks. Urine is better than blood to detect arsenic poisoning.
  5. Arsenic also gets deposited in hair, nails, skin and bones where it remains for a much more prolonged time (even for years) after exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbon monoxide: Carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin in the blood but does not leave detectable residues in skeletal remains.

 

Option C. Hydrogen sulphide: Hydrogen sulphide is a gas that affects soft tissues and is not detected in skeletal remains.

 

Option D. Phosphorus: Phosphorus can affect soft tissues but is not typically detected in bones long after death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arsenic can be found in skeletal remains for several years after death due to its strong binding to the bone matrix and slow release over time.

questions.text: X, Y, Z are three permeable ions. X = -50 and Y = -30. At RMP, if there is no net electrogenic transfer, what is the value of Z? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) + 80

 

No net electrogenic transfer at RMP implies that X + Y + Z = 0

 

So, - 50 + (-30) + Z =0

 

Z = 50 + 30 = 80

 

Educational Objective:

 

No net electrogenic transfer at resting membrane potential (RMP) implies that the sum of the equilibrium potentials of the ions is zero

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the clinic with complaints of oral ulcers and a burning sensation in the mouth. A picture of the patient's oral cavity is provided, which reveals several white patches on the tongue and inner cheek. Based on this presentation, what is the likely diagnosis for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leukoplakia

 

  • Leukoplakia is characterized by the presence of white patches on the oral mucosa, which cannot be scraped off.
  • The patches may vary in appearance, from smooth to rough or nodular.
  • Common risk factors include tobacco use (both smoking and smokeless forms) and chronic alcohol consumption.
  • While it's a benign lesion, there is a risk of malignant transformation, which is why regular monitoring and biopsy of suspicious areas are vital.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Erythroplakia: Erythroplakia is less common than leukoplakia but has a higher potential for being either cancerous at the time of diagnosis or becoming malignant later. It appears as red patches or plaques and is often more concerning due to its higher risk of malignancy.

 

Option C. Submucosal fibrosis: Oral submucous fibrosis is a chronic, progressive scarring disease, mostly linked to areca nut (betel nut) chewing. It's particularly prevalent in the Indian subcontinent. It's characterized by stiffness of the oral mucosa leading to trismus (difficulty in opening the mouth), burning sensation on eating spicy food, and oral ulcers. Over time, the condition can progress, making it hard for the patient to open their mouth. This condition also has a risk of malignant transformation, and like leukoplakia, requires regular monitoring.

 

Option D. Malakoplakia: Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory condition that can affect various organs, including the bladder, kidneys, and even the gastrointestinal tract. In the context of the oral cavity, it's extremely rare. It presents as soft yellow plaques. Histologically, it's characterized by the presence of unique cells called "Michaelis-Gutmann bodies".

 

  • Given the presentation described - white patches on the tongue and inner cheek of a chronic alcohol abuser - the diagnosis of leukoplakia (option A) is the most probable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leukoplakia is an oral mucosal lesion characterized by white patches that cannot be scraped off and is commonly associated with tobacco and alcohol use.
  • It has the potential for malignant transformation, necessitating regular monitoring and biopsy of suspicious areas.

questions.text: Which of the following new drugs has been approved for the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Edaravone

 

Edaravone is an FDA approved drug used in the treatment of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

 

It has free radical scavenging properties that may reduce oxidative stress although the exact mechanism of action is unknown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Piracetam: Piracetam is used off-label for cognitive enhancement and the treatment of myoclonus. It is not approved for the treatment of ALS.

 

Option C. Dabrafenib: Dabrafenib is a targeted therapy used for the treatment of BRAF V600E mutation-positive melanoma. It is not used for ALS.

 

Option D. Trametinib: Trametinib is also used for the treatment of BRAF V600E mutation-positive melanoma. It is not indicated for ALS.

 

Educational Objective

 

Edaravone is the new drug approved for the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), primarily due to its free radical scavenging properties that may help reduce oxidative stress, a factor involved in the disease's progression.

choices.text: Get consent from mother for P/V

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to you with her mother, reporting abdominal discomfort and is found to be 12 weeks pregnant based on a positive urine pregnancy test. As a medical professional, what would be your initial course of action? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Inform Police

 

Explanation

 

In many jurisdictions, pregnancy in a minor may be considered evidence of statutory rape or sexual abuse, hence, informing the police is crucial for legal proceedings and safeguarding the minor.

 

Other Option

 

Option A. Start examining: Although a medical examination is necessary, it must be conducted with proper legal and parental consent, especially considering the age and the situation's sensitivity.

 

Option C. Preserve clothing: This could be necessary in a case where forensic evidence needs to be gathered, especially if there was recent assault. However, this would follow legal reporting.

 

Option D. Take consent from mother: Consent is crucial, especially for minors. However, it does not preclude the obligation to report statutory rape or sexual abuse to authorities.

 

Educational objective :

 

  • When dealing with potentially criminal situations involving minors, such as a young teenager's pregnancy, the first step is to ensure the situation is addressed legally and safely. 
  • Informing law enforcement and ensuring proper medical and legal procedures safeguard the minor's health and legal rights.

questions.text: Alpha 1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elastase

 

Alpha 1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme neutrophil elastase.

 

On serum electrophoresis, alpha-1-antitrypsin (-1-AT), also known as alpha 1-protease inhibitor, is a glycoprotein that typically makes up the alpha1-globulin fraction of the plasma proteins.

 

It is typically produced in the liver and found in macrophages, circulating blood, and tissue fluids.

 

The name "Alpha1-protease inhibitor" comes from the fact that alpha1AT's primary role in the body is to inhibit proteases. The proteases, particularly the elastases, come from neutrophils.

 

The anti-elastase activity of alpha1-AT prevents neutrophil elastase from digesting lung parenchyma, despite its ability to do so.

 

In the proteinase inhibitor (Pi) locus on chromosome 14, co-dominantly expressed genes that code for 1-antitrypsin are located. The Pi locus has a wide variety of alleles and is highly polymorphic.

 

Those who have the alpha1-AT deficit develop panacinar pulmonary emphysema.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase: Not primarily inhibited by A1AT; it is an antioxidant enzyme.

 

Option B. Collagenase: Also not a primary target of A1AT; these enzymes break down collagen in connective tissue.

 

Option D. Phospholipase: Not inhibited by A1AT; involved in the hydrolysis of phospholipids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha 1-antitrypsin's critical role is to inhibit neutrophil elastase, thus protecting connective tissue from inflammatory damage, particularly in the lungs and liver.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy was brought to the casualty with seizures. The pediatrician tries to do CSF sampling. What are the structures punctured by the pediatrician while piercing through the marked structure? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scalp, dura, arachnoid

 

Explanation:

 

The arrow in the illustration, which displays a baby's skull, is pointing in the direction of the anterior fontanelle. Ventricular tapping is the term used to describe the process of removing CSF from the anterior fontanelle. The various structures pierced are the scalp, dura, and arachnoid.

 

Fontanelle tap/ Percutaneous ventricular puncture:

 

Infants who need urgent ventricular decompression and have an open anterior fontanelle and no access to a VP shunt undergo a fontanelle tap or percutaneous ventricular puncture. A butterfly needle is used to immediately puncture the infant's open fontanelle and enter the lateral ventricle in order to obtain CS samples, alleviate pressure, or insert a drain or catheter.

 

Procedure: A 25-gauge butterfly needle is inserted through the anterolateral aspect of the anterior fontanelle (away from the midline, avoiding the superior sagittal sinus).

 

When performing a fontanelle tap, the following layers are pierced:

 

  • Scalp: This includes the skin and the underlying connective tissue of the scalp.
  • Membranous fontanelle: The actual fontanelle is a soft spot on a baby's head where the bones of the skull have not yet fused together. It's a membranous gap between the cranial bones.
  • Dura mater: The tough outermost membrane of the three layers of the meninges that surround the brain and spinal cord.
  • Arachnoid mater: A thin, wispy layer that lies underneath the dura mater.
  • Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF): Once through the arachanoid mater, the needle enters the subarachnoid space where the CSF is located.

 

Note: The fontanelle tap bypasses the bony skull, which is why it's an accessible route in neonates and infants for procedures that require access to the CSF. However, as the child grows, these fontanelles close, and the method is no longer viable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fontanelle tap is a critical emergency procedure used in infants for CSF sampling or pressure relief from the ventricles, exploiting the unossified sections of the skull for direct access to the CSF. This procedure is unique to neonates and young infants where the fontanelle is present and typically involves piercing the scalp, dura, and arachnoid layers.

questions.text: What is the normal uterocervical length?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 7 cm

 

Explanation:

 

  • The normal length of the uterine cavity, including the cervical canal, is usually 6-7 cm. This measurement is essential in gynecological evaluations and procedures.
  • This measurement helps in assessing normal uterine anatomy and can be used in various clinical procedures such as the insertion of intrauterine devices (IUDs).
  • Ovary: The ovary measures about 3 cm x 2 cm x 1 cm.
  • Fallopian Tube: The length of the Fallopian tube is about 10 cm, and the lumen is 1-2 mm at the isthmus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal length of the uterine cavity, including the cervical canal, is 6-7 cm.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition Pg 25, Dutta's textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 7

questions.text: The blood supply to the structure marked in the image is by? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior cerebral artery

 

Explanation:

 

The marked structure is fornix which is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.

 

The optic chiasma, lamina terminalis, hypothalamus, para-olfactory regions, and cingulate gyrus are all supplied by the anteromedial central branches of the anterior cerebral artery in addition to the fornix.

 

The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers in the brain that plays a crucial role in memory and cognitive functions. It is supplied by

 

  1. Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA): The ACA is one of the major arteries of the Circle of Willis and is responsible for supplying blood to the frontal lobes of the brain, including the anterior part of the fornix.
  2. Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA): The PCA is another major artery of the Circle of Willis, and its branches supply blood to the posterior part of the fornix.
  3. Anterior Choroidal Artery: This artery arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies blood to the choroid plexus in the lateral and third ventricles of the brain. It also sends branches to the fornix, particularly the inferior part.
  4. Septal Branches: The fornix also receives blood supply from septal branches, which originate from the anterior cerebral arteries. Top of Form

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Cervical mucus thickening
Increase GnRH release

questions.text: Oral contraceptives act by all of the following mechanisms except: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase GnRH release

 

Explanation:

 

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) function through several mechanisms to prevent pregnancy, but increasing the release of Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) is not one of them. In fact, OCPs inhibit the release of GnRH.

 

Mechanisms of action of OCPs:

 

  • Inhibit ovulation: By suppressing the release of GnRH, and consequently, the pituitary secretion of Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and Luteinizing Hormone (LH), OCPs prevent the development and release of an ovum.
  • Prevent implantation: OCPs create a less favorable endometrial environment for implantation of a fertilized egg.
  • Cervical mucus thickening: OCPs increase the viscosity of cervical mucus, making it more difficult for sperm to enter the uterus and fertilize an ovum.
  • Produce static endometrial hypoplasia: OCPs cause the endometrial lining to remain thin, which further prevents implantation.
  • Affect tubal motility: OCPs can alter the motility of the fallopian tubes, reducing the likelihood of sperm meeting an ovum.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Inhibit implantation: OCPs prevent the endometrium from becoming suitable for implantation.

 

Option B. Cervical mucus thickening: OCPs increase the thickness of cervical mucus to block sperm penetration.

 

Option C. Inhibit ovulation: OCPs suppress the hormonal signals that trigger ovulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral contraceptive pills prevent pregnancy by inhibiting ovulation, preventing implantation, thickening cervical mucus, producing static endometrial hypoplasia, and affecting tubal motility. They do not increase GnRH release; rather, they inhibit it.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition 485

questions.text: A patient with gout develops hypertension. The uric acid level was found to be elevated. Which of the following is not administered? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that can lead to Hyperuricemia as its side effect. So, it should not be used in the management of hypertension in a patient with gout. The other side effects of thiazides include Hypokalemia, Metabolic alkalosis, Hyperglycemia, Hypomagnesemia and Hypercalcemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atenolol: Atenolol is a beta-blocker that does not typically affect uric acid levels and is considered safe for use in patients with gout.

 

Option C. Enalapril: Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor that does not increase uric acid levels and is suitable for managing hypertension in patients with gout.

 

Option D. Prazosin: Prazosin is an alpha-blocker that does not affect uric acid levels and can be safely used in patients with gout.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrochlorothiazide should not be used to manage hypertension in patients with gout due to its potential to increase uric acid levels and exacerbate the condition. Other antihypertensive drugs, such as beta-blockers (atenolol), ACE inhibitors (enalapril), and alpha-blockers (prazosin), do not have this adverse effect and are suitable alternatives.

choices.text: Enteric nervous system neurons
Smooth muscle cells of the GI tract
Interstitial cells of Cajal

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) presents with complaints of intermittent abdominal cramping and altered bowel movements. During the consultation, his physician explains the role of gastrointestinal motility and how certain cells generate rhythmic electrical activity that controls the contraction of the GI smooth muscles. What is the source of generation for slow waves in the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Interstitial cells of Cajal

 

Explanation:

 

The interstitial cells of Cajal (ICC) are specialized pacemaker cells within the gastrointestinal tract that generate slow waves, which are rhythmic oscillations in membrane potential. These cells are strategically positioned between the layers of smooth muscle in the GI tract and form a network that communicates with smooth muscle cells via synaptic-like connections. The slow waves generated by ICCs are due to cyclic changes in membrane potential caused by unique ion channels that periodically open, creating pacemaker currents. These slow waves set the basic rhythm of GI motility by modulating the frequency and timing of muscle contractions, although they do not directly cause contractions themselves except in the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enteric nervous system neurons
The enteric nervous system regulates many functions of the GI tract, including muscle contraction, but it does not generate the slow waves. Instead, it modulates the activity of the interstitial cells of Cajal and smooth muscle cells.

 

Option B. Smooth muscle cells of the GI tract
Smooth muscle cells respond to slow waves but do not generate them. The slow waves trigger intermittent spike potentials in smooth muscle cells, leading to muscle contraction, but the pacemaking activity originates from the interstitial cells of Cajal.

 

Option D. Vagus nerve stimulation
The vagus nerve plays an essential role in regulating GI motility and secretion by interacting with the enteric nervous system, but it does not generate slow waves. Its action primarily involves modulating the frequency and strength of contractions driven by the interstitial cells of Cajal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Slow waves in the gastrointestinal tract are generated by the interstitial cells of Cajal, which act as pacemaker cells, creating rhythmic electrical activity that sets the basic rhythm of GI motility. This activity is crucial for coordinating smooth muscle contractions and ensuring proper movement of contents through the digestive system.

questions.text: An individual undergoes a bone marrow examination which shows the presence of the cells as shown in the image. Which of the following is the likely enzyme defect associated with this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocerebrosidase

 

The presence of gaucher cells with a crumpled paper appearance is suggestive of Gaucher’s disease. It is caused by deficiency of glucocerebrosidase.

 

Gaucher's Disease:

 

  • Pathology: Gaucher's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glucocerebroside into glucose and ceramide.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and bone pain or fractures.
  • Histopathology: Gaucher cells are macrophages filled with lipid-laden lysosomes. These cells have a characteristic crumpled paper appearance due to the accumulation of glucocerebroside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hexosaminidase: Deficiency causes Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by a cherry-red spot on the macula.

 

Option C. Alpha 1,4 glucosidase: Deficiency causes Pompe disease, characterized by glycogen accumulation in lysosomes.

 

Option D. Galactosidase: Deficiency causes Fabry disease, characterized by angiokeratomas, acroparesthesia, and renal failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher cells with a crumpled paper appearance in a bone marrow examination are indicative of Gaucher's disease, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

 

Gaucher Disease Overview:

choices.text: Moderate or regular exercise for 30 min
Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors
