questions.text: Which of the following measures are associated with an increased life span? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent

 

Decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent will increase lifespan.

 

Caloric restriction reduces the severity of oxidative damage as well as the resulting decline in function. It lowers the steady-state concentrations of oxidative damage products in proteins, DNA, and lipids. This is due to a decrease in mitochondrial superoxide anion and hydrogen peroxide production and an increase in antioxidant production. Caloric restriction slows the rate of energy metabolism overall.

 

Caloric restriction postpones the onset of age-related diseases like cancer (including lymphomas, breast and prostate cancers), nephropathy, and cataracts. Caloric restriction also reduces the onset of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and the development of autoimmune diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Moderate or regular exercise for 30 min: While exercise has numerous health benefits and can improve quality of life and reduce the risk of chronic diseases, it has not been directly linked to the same extent of lifespan extension as caloric restriction in scientific studies.

 

Option B. Decrease stress: Reducing stress can improve health outcomes and prevent stress-related diseases, but specific lifespan extension evidence is less robust compared to caloric restriction.

 

Option D. Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors: Proton pump inhibitors are used to treat gastrointestinal conditions like acid reflux and ulcers. They are not associated with increased lifespan and may have adverse effects if used long-term.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caloric restriction, by decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent, is associated with an increased lifespan and the postponement of age-related diseases. It reduces oxidative damage, slows metabolism, and mitigates the onset of various chronic conditions.

questions.text: What is the most frequent cause of adrenal incidentaloma? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-functioning adenoma

 

Most frequent cause of adrenal incidentaloma is Non-functioning adenoma

 

An adrenal incidentaloma is an unexpected adrenal mass detected on imaging not performed for suspected adrenal disease.

 

Non-functioning adrenal adenomas do not secrete hormones in significant amounts to cause clinical syndromes. They are benign tumors that are often discovered incidentally on imaging studies. Histologically, they are similar to hormone-secreting adenomas, but they do not produce clinical symptoms or biochemical abnormalities. They are the most common type of adrenal incidentaloma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subclinical Cushing's syndrome: Subclinical Cushing's syndrome refers to the mild or asymptomatic cortisol excess from an adrenal adenoma. These patients lack the full-blown signs and symptoms of overt Cushing's syndrome but might show subtle manifestations of cortisol excess or have abnormal laboratory findings.

 

Option B. Aldosterone producing adenoma: Aldosterone producing adenomas are a cause of primary hyperaldosteronism. They produce excess aldosterone leading to hypertension and hypokalemia. Patients may have suppressed renin levels in the blood due to feedback inhibition from the elevated aldosterone.

 

Option C. Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytomas are tumors of the adrenal medulla that produce excessive amounts of catecholamines (e.g., epinephrine and norepinephrine). Symptoms often include paroxysms of hypertension, headache, sweating, and palpitations. While these are serious tumors, they are a less common cause of adrenal incidentalomas.

choices.text: Urine specimen is used
Sanger sequencing is used
Study of fluid in tumor microenvironment
DNA is collected in micro vessels

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding liquid-based cytology? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urine specimen is used

 

Liquid-based cytology can also be done using a urine specimen. It is commonly used in cervical cancer screening in place of a pap smear.

 

Liquid-based cytology is a method of preparing samples for examination in cytopathology. The sample is collected, normally by a small brush, in the same way as for a conventional smear test, but rather than the smear being transferred directly to a microscope slide, the sample is deposited into a small bottle of preservative liquid. At the laboratory, the liquid is treated to remove other elements such as mucus before a layer of cells is placed on a slide.

 

Liquid-based cytology uses:

 

  • Used in place of PAP smear for cervical screening (most common use)
  • Thyroid cyst fluid examination.
  • Oral lesions
  • Body fluids sampling (e.g., urine, pleural effusions), brushing samples (e.g. gastrointestinal tract, lung), and fine needle aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sanger sequencing is used: Sanger sequencing is a method of DNA sequencing and is not related to liquid-based cytology.

 

Option C. Study of fluid in tumor microenvironment: Liquid-based cytology is not specifically focused on the study of tumor microenvironment fluids; rather, it is a method for preparing and analyzing cellular samples.

 

Option D. DNA is collected in micro vessels: This is not a description of liquid-based cytology but may relate to other molecular biology techniques.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liquid-based cytology can use urine specimens, among others, to prepare samples for cytological examination, offering advantages over traditional smear techniques in terms of sample preservation and clarity.

choices.text: It is the most common type of squint.
Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio.
It is associated with high myopia.
Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding accommodative esotropia? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is associated with high myopia.

 

Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of esotropia and is associated with hypermetropia (farsightedness), not myopia (nearsightedness). The condition often presents in children around 2 to 3 years of age and is characterized by an inward turning of the eyes that is related to the effort of focusing (accommodation).

 

Types:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the most common type of squint: True. Accommodative esotropia is indeed the most common type of esotropia seen in children. This type of squint is related to the effort of focusing (accommodation) and is associated with farsightedness (hypermetropia).

 

Option B. Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio: True. Miotics can be used to manage accommodative esotropia associated with a high AC/A ratio. Miotics reduce the need for accommodation, thereby reducing the associated esotropia.

 

Option D. Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles: True. The refractive type of accommodative esotropia can be fully corrected by using spectacles that correct the hypermetropia. These spectacles reduce the accommodative effort, thereby correcting the esotropia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Accommodative esotropia, the most common type of squint, is associated with high hypermetropia and can often be fully corrected by spectacles. It is not associated with high myopia. Different treatment strategies, including the use of spectacles and bifocals, depend on the specific type and underlying cause of the esotropia.

choices.text: A, B, D
A, C, D
A and C
A and D

questions.text:
Choose the correct options regarding the route of administration and bioavailability:  (INICET MAY 2022)

 

A - Intravenous = 1

B - 0.75 < Oral <1

C - 0.75 < IM (Intramuscular) <1

D - 0.75 < SC (Subcutaneous) <1
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A, C, D

 

To evaluate these options, we need to understand the route of administration and bioavailability for each:

 

  1. Intravenous (IV): The bioavailability of a drug administered intravenously is always 1 (or 100%) because it directly enters the systemic circulation without any barriers to absorption.
  2. Oral: The bioavailability of oral medications is typically less than 1 (or 100%) because of the first-pass metabolism (metabolic degradation of a drug before it reaches systemic circulation) and variable absorption in the gastrointestinal tract.
  3. Intramuscular (IM): The bioavailability of IM administered drugs is typically high but usually less than 1 due to factors like local blood flow and muscle type. It is often close to 1 but not always 100%.
  4. Subcutaneous (SC): Similar to IM, the bioavailability of drugs administered subcutaneously is usually high but typically less than 1 due to absorption factors at the injection site.

 

Given this information:

 

  • A (Intravenous = 1) is correct.
  • C (0.75 < IM < 1) is plausible, but like oral administration, the lower limit is not a fixed value.
  • D (0.75 < SC < 1) follows the same reasoning as IM; it's generally true but with a variable lower limit.

 

Other Options:

 

  • B. (0.75 < Oral < 1) is plausible, although the lower limit of 0.75 is arbitrary and not universally applicable as oral bioavailability can vary widely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most accurate answer, considering the typical bioavailability ranges for these routes, is B. A, C, D. However, it's important to note that specific values (like 0.75) provided for oral, IM, and SC routes are not absolute and can vary depending on the drug and other factors.

choices.text: Karyotyping of the parents

questions.text: A female comes to Gynecology OPD for pre-conceptual counseling, with 2 prior second trimester abortions. What is the next investigation you will advise? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelvic sonography

 

Explanation:

 

The most common cause of recurrent second trimester pregnancy loss (RPL) is anatomical abnormalities of the uterus. The initial investigation for anatomical abnormalities is a transvaginal ultrasound (pelvic sonography) as it is non-invasive and provides detailed imaging of the uterine structure.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Recurrent first trimester abortions: Often associated with antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA) or endocrinological causes.
  • Recurrent second trimester abortions: Often associated with anatomical uterine problems.
  • Single spontaneous abortion: Most commonly caused by fetal genetic abnormalities.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hysterosalpingography: This is not routinely advised for anatomical abnormalities of the uterus. It is more commonly used for evaluating tubal patency and uterine cavity shape but is not the first-line investigation in this scenario.

 

Option C. Endometrial Biopsy: This is advised in women with suspected genital tuberculosis or in women with suspected luteal phase defect. It is not typically indicated for recurrent second trimester pregnancy loss.

 

Option D. Karyotyping of the parents: Chromosomal abnormalities, such as balanced translocations, account for only about 5% of recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL). Therefore, parental karyotyping is not an initial investigation of choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial investigation for recurrent second trimester pregnancy loss (RPL) is pelvic sonography to evaluate for anatomical abnormalities of the uterus.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 2t6h edition pg 203

choices.text: Lateral edge of pectoralis major muscle
Lateral border of latissimus dorsi muscle

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of the triangle of safety for chest tube insertion in a patient with pneumothorax on chest X-ray? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mid-axillary line

 

The mid-axillary line is not a boundary of the triangle of safety. The triangle of safety is defined by specific anatomical landmarks and includes the lateral edge of the pectoralis major muscle, Latissimus dorse, and the fifth intercostal space inferiorly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral edge of pectoralis major muscle: This is the anterior boundary of the triangle of safety.

 

Option C. Base of axilla: This is a boundary of the triangle of safety. It is an important reference point for chest tube insertion to ensure it is performed safely and effectively.

 

Option D. Lateral border of latissimus dorsi muscle: This is a boundary of the triangle of safety. It helps guide the placement of the chest tube in a safe and appropriate location.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triangle of safety for chest tube insertion is a surgical landmark used to guide the safe insertion of chest tubes in patients with pneumothorax. The boundaries of the triangle are the lateral edge of the pectoralis major muscle, the lateral border of the latissimus dorsi muscle, and the 5th intercostal space (ICS) inferiorly, at the level of the nipple above and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle. The base of the triangle is formed by the anterior border of the latissimus dorsi muscle and the lateral edge of the serratus anterior muscle at the base of the axilla.

choices.text: It activates large-diameter afferent fibers that inhibit pain signals in the spinal cord.
It increases local blood flow to painful areas, providing muscle relaxation and pain relief.
It stimulates the release of endorphins at the site of stimulation, providing local analgesia.
It disrupts the transmission of pain signals by depolarizing nociceptive neurons directly

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with chronic low back pain secondary to degenerative disc disease has been referred to physical therapy for pain management. Her pain has been poorly controlled with medications, and her physician recommends transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) as a complementary therapy. She asks how TENS works to relieve her pain. Which of the following best explains the mechanism of action of TENS in reducing pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. It activates large-diameter afferent fibers that inhibit pain signals in the spinal cord.

 

Explanation:

 

TENS works by stimulating large-diameter afferent fibers, such as A-beta fibers, which activate the gate control mechanism in the spinal cord. This mechanism, located primarily in the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn, inhibits the transmission of pain signals carried by smaller nociceptive fibers like A-delta and C fibers. The activation of these large fibers "closes the gate" to pain, reducing the perception of pain. This modulation of pain signals through the spinal cord's gate control system is a key component of TENS therapy, contributing to its analgesic effect.

 

.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It increases local blood flow to painful areas, providing muscle relaxation and pain relief.
While increased blood flow may occur as a secondary effect, TENS does not primarily relieve pain through this mechanism. The primary action of TENS is the activation of large-diameter afferent fibers to inhibit pain transmission at the spinal level.

 

Option C. It stimulates the release of endorphins at the site of stimulation, providing local analgesia.
Endorphin release can contribute to pain relief, but TENS primarily acts at the spinal level to inhibit pain signal transmission rather than directly increasing endorphin release at the stimulation site.

 

Option D. It disrupts the transmission of pain signals by depolarizing nociceptive neurons directly.
TENS does not directly depolarize nociceptive neurons; instead, it works by modulating spinal cord circuits and descending inhibitory pathways to reduce pain transmission through indirect mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) alleviates pain by activating large-diameter afferent fibers, which engage the gate control mechanism in the spinal cord to inhibit pain transmission. This process reduces the flow of pain signals to the brain, providing analgesia, and represents a non-invasive method of pain control often used in chronic pain management settings.

questions.text: A child is presenting with palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, and pain in the knee joint resulting from arthritis. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Henoch-Schonlein purpura

 

The combination of palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, joint pain resulting from arthritis, and urinary findings of hematuria and proteinuria is characteristic of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

 

The clinical presentation and the investigations are suggestive of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a systemic immune disorder characterized by a purpuric rash, abdominal pain, polyarthralgia, and renal abnormalities. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years.

 

The patient may present with the following clinical features:

 

  • Skin lesions- These typically involve the extensor surfaces of the arms and legs, as well as the buttocks.
  • Pain, vomiting, and intestinal bleeding are examples of abdominal manifestations.
  • Renal manifestations include hematuria, nephritic syndrome, and nephrotic syndrome. Adults have more severe renal manifestations. Some patients develop a rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura: typically presents with isolated thrombocytopenia and mucocutaneous bleeding, without joint pain or abdominal pain.

 

Option B. Dengue fever: Dengue fever is a viral illness that typically presents with fever, headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, and rash.

 

Option C. Churg-Strauss syndrome: Churg-Strauss syndrome is a rare systemic autoimmune disease that typically presents with asthma, eosinophilia, and systemic vasculitis, often involving multiple organs. While arthritis may be seen in Churg-Strauss syndrome, palpable purpura is uncommon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henoch-Schonlein purpura is characterized by the presence of palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthritis, and renal involvement, typically manifesting as hematuria and proteinuria. It is a small vessel vasculitis most commonly affecting children and is distinguished by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in affected tissues.

choices.text: Cell membrane blebs and loss of microvilli
Nuclear changes like pyknosis and karyolysis

questions.text: Which is the most important light microscopic feature of irreversible cell injury? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nuclear changes like pyknosis and karyolysis

 

The most important light microscopic features of irreversible cell injury are nuclear changes. These changes are indicative of cell death and include:

 

  • Pyknosis: The nucleus shrinks and becomes dense, with chromatin condensing into a solid, darkly staining mass.
  • Karyorrhexis: The pyknotic nucleus fragments into smaller pieces.
  • Karyolysis: The nuclear fragments dissolve and fade, leading to the eventual loss of the nucleus.

 

These nuclear changes are hallmark signs of irreversible cell damage and cell death, distinguishing them from reversible changes such as cellular swelling or detachment of ribosomes from the endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amorphous densities in mitochondria: These changes are often seen in irreversible cell injury, particularly in the context of mitochondrial dysfunction, but nuclear changes are more definitive indicators of irreversible damage.

 

Option B. Cell membrane blebs and loss of microvilli: These features are associated with reversible cell injury, not irreversible injury. They indicate cellular swelling and loss of structural integrity but do not signify cell death.

 

Option C. Ribosomal detachment from endoplasmic reticulum: This is also a feature of reversible cell injury, indicating disruption in protein synthesis, but it does not define irreversible injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyknosis, karyorrhexis, and karyolysis on light microscopy are signs of irreversible cell injury.

choices.text: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia
Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia
Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
Acute Myeloid Leukemia

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is being evaluated for leukemia. On investigation, WBC count was 4,50,000 /µL with eosinophilia and basophilia. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia  

 

A WBC count of 4,50,000/µL with eosinophilia and basophilia indicates a probable diagnosis of Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia presents with pancytopenia

 

Option C. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia shows smudge cells and small round lymphocytes in peripheral smear.

 

Option D. Acute Myeloid Leukemia: Acute Myeloid Leukemia shows myeloblasts with Auer rods. Clinically, patients have pancytopenia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia is characterized by extreme leukocytosis with eosinophilia and basophilia, and it is associated with the Philadelphia chromosome and the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has a history of urinating in public without having any remorse for it. She also has difficulty in getting motivated and has mild memory deficits. Which of the following lobes may be affected? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frontal

 

The frontal lobe is responsible for executive functions, social behavior, motivation, and impulse control. Damage to the frontal lobe can result in disinhibited behaviors, such as socially inappropriate actions (e.g., urinating in public without remorse), lack of motivation (apathy), and mild memory impairments. These changes are often seen in conditions affecting the frontal lobe, including frontal lobe syndrome or neurodegenerative diseases. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parietal Lobe: Primarily responsible for sensation and spatial processing. Lesions here might manifest as sensory deficits or spatial disorientation, rather than the behavioral issues described.

 

Option B. Occipital Lobe: Concerned with vision. Deficits or lesions here primarily manifest as visual disturbances, not behavioral or motivational issues.

 

Option D. Temporal Lobe: Associated with auditory processing, memory, and emotion. Although it does play a role in memory, the other symptoms described are more consistent with frontal lobe dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Frontal Lobe is involved in executive functions, decision-making, motivation, and socially appropriate behavior. Damage can lead to disinhibited behavior, apathy, and memory deficits.

 

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 346-348.

questions.text: What is the most important assessment based on the treatment given to the patient and their clinical management in a health care facility? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Process

 

Evaluation of "process" can assess a health care facility based on the treatment given to the patient and their clinical management.

 

The process of evaluation involves several steps, such as

 

  • Determining what needs to be evaluated
  • Establishing standards and criteria
  • Planning the methodology
  • Gathering information
  • Analyzing the results
  • Taking action
  • Re-evaluating

 

There are three types of evaluation: structure evaluation, process evaluation, and outcome evaluation.

 

  1. Evaluation of "structure": This is evaluation of whether facilities, equipment, manpower and organization meet a standard accepted by experts as good.
  2. Evaluation of "process": The process of medical care includes the problems of recognition, diagnostic procedures, treatment and clinical management, care and prevention. The way in which the various activities of the programme is carried out is evaluated by comparing with a predetermined standard. An objective and systematic way of evaluating the physician (or nurse) performance is known as "Medical (or nursing) Audit"
  3. Evaluation of "outcome": This is concerned with the end results, that is, whether persons using health services experience measurable benefits such as improved survival or reduced disability. The traditional outcome components are the "5 Ds" of ill-health, viz. disease, discomfort, dissatisfaction, disability and death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Outcome: Focuses on the end results of healthcare, such as improved health status and reduced disease and disability.

 

  • Not Correct: It measures the results of care, not the processes used to deliver it.

 

Option C. Structure: Examines the physical and organizational infrastructure, like facilities, equipment, and staffing.

 

  • Not Correct: It evaluates resources and infrastructure, not the actual delivery of care.

 

Option D. Input: Assesses resources required for healthcare, such as funding, manpower, and materials.

 

  • Not Correct: It looks at the resources used, not how care is delivered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "process" evaluation is the most relevant assessment for determining the quality of treatment and clinical management provided to patients in a healthcare facility. It focuses on the procedures and methods used in patient care, ensuring adherence to established standards and guidelines.

choices.text: MRI to rule out enlarged heart

questions.text: The parents notice that their child is tired and that he has shortness of breath on climbing stairs and while lying down. What is the first investigation that you would do? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chest x-ray

 

The first investigation to be done for a child who feels shortness of breath on climbing stairs and in the supine position is a chest x-ray.

 

The child having shortness of breath on dyspnea on exertion worsened in the supine position is orthopnea could be suggestive of congestive heart failure.

 

Causes -

 

  1. Respiratory causes include asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD), pneumonia, and pulmonary embolism.
  2. Cardiovascular causes include congestive heart failure (CH), pulmonary edema, valvular heart defect, and pulmonary hypertension.

 

Evaluation

 

  • Oxygen saturation at rest and during physical activity
  • Chest x-ray is the first diagnostic test as pulmonary pathology or pulmonary edema and signs of CHF may be seen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: An echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac cause if the chest X-ray is abnormal

 

Option C: Spirometry to assess lung function when the chest x-ray is normal.

 

Option D: Cardiac MRI (Magnetic resonance imaging) is an emerging modality done to look for cardiomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a child presenting with shortness of breath on exertion and orthopnea, the first investigation should be a chest x-ray to evaluate potential pulmonary pathology and signs of congestive heart failure.
